thread.title: The Morning Risk Report: Huawei Looks to Avoid ZTE’s Fate

author: Samuel Rubenfeld
title: The Morning Risk Report: Huawei Looks to Avoid ZTE’s Fate
text:
0 COMMENTS Readers can subscribe to The Morning Risk Report here: http://on.wsj.com/MorningRiskReportSignup . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Huawei faces potential penaltie if investigators find it violated U.S. export laws. Reuters Good morning. Huawei Technologies Co. abandoned its plans for a bond sale after The Wall Street Journal reported the U.S. Justice Department is investigating whether the Chinese cellular giant violated sanctions on Iran.
Huawei is trying to avoid the fate of smaller rival ZTE ZTE is fighting allegations that led to a seven-year denial of access to U.S.-made components after the U.S. Commerce Department accused the firm of lying about its adherence to a $1.19 billion settlement concerning Iran sanctions violations.
American component suppliers are finding themselves caught in the middle of the probes. Several ZTE vendors saw their stock prices fall in the wake of the U.S. ban, and shares of several Huawei suppliers dropped following news of the Justice Department probe.
Huawei didn’t give a reason for canceling the bond sale, said the WSJ report, citing a money manager who saw a notice about the company’s change in plans. “In spite of the overwhelming responses” from investors during the euro debt offering the company decided to put the bond issue on hold, a Huawei spokesman told the Journal.
The company faces potential criminal and civil penalties, and potential prosecution of culpable individuals, if investigators find it violated U.S. export laws.
Huawei, the world’s third-largest maker of smartphones, hasn’t commented on the sanctions probe. It’s unclear how far prosecutors have advanced and what specific allegations are under investigation, according to the Journal.
EXCLUSIVE ON RISK AND COMPLIANCE JOURNAL
Whistleblowers hope for ally at IRS. Tipsters have helped the Internal Revenue Service collect $3.6 billion since 2007. Whistleblower lawyers hope Charles Rettig, the potential next leader of the agency, will make it easier to bring in still more cash.
Sanctions end for Colombian soccer club. The U.S. Treasury Department said Thursday it lifted sanctions on Envigado FC , a Colombian soccer team, after the nation’s government oversaw a forced sale, severing the team’s ties to organized crime.
Defense contractor settles export case. Flir Systems agreed to settle U.S. allegations it violated laws restricting military-related exports. The total penalty is $30 million, but the State Department said it suspended payment of half on the condition the funds will be used for department-approved remedial compliance measures.
COMPLIANCE
Bill Cosby is found guilty. A jury found entertainer Bill Cosby guilty Thursday of sexually assaulting a woman at his home in 2004, in the first major prosecution since the #MeToo movement put the issue of sexual assault by powerful men onto the U.S. national stage, the WSJ reports.
Actor and comedian Bill Cosby leaves the courtroom Thursday after being found guilty in his sexual-assault trial in Norristown, Pa. PHOTO: DOMINICK REUTER/AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE/GETTY IMAGES China moves to police its history. China’s legislature is set to pass a new law that requires “all of society” to “honor, study and defend” Communist Party-approved heroes and martyrs. The law will subject anyone who defames members of that select group to potential criminal penalties and civil liabilities, the WSJ reports.
SEC fines Welsh Carson over fee disclosure. The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission penalized private-equity firm Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe for failing to disclose to investors the fees it received for the bulk purchase of supplies. WCAS Management Corp., the adviser for Welsh Carson’s funds, agreed to pay about $779,000, the WSJ reports.
Ex-HSBC executive faces prison time. Mark Johnson, a former high-ranking HSBC Holdings PLC executive was sentenced to two years in prison. He was convicted last fall on charges that he misused confidential information about a client’s $3.5 billion currency trade to make millions of dollars for the bank.
DATA SECURITY
U.S. executives uncertain over GDPR. Three in four U.S. business executives with some level of responsibility over data said they were uncertain about the scope of Europe’s General Data Protection Regulation, which takes effect in less than a month, or thought the rule applies only to European or multinational organizations, the IT trade group CompTIA reports, according to the WSJ.
REPUTATION
Starbucks chief vows to learn from arrests. Starbucks Chief Executive Kevin Johnson said he is “personally committed” to preventing an incident like the arrest of two black men at one of its coffee shops in Philadelphia this month from reoccurring, the WSJ reports.
Wynn CEO to face regulators. Wynn Resorts Ltd. Chief Executive Matt Maddox is set to appear before Massachusetts gambling regulators Friday to stress that the company has restructured its board and worked to change its culture in the wake of sexual misconduct allegations against founder Steve Wynn, the WSJ reports.
Senate tells off Menendez. The U.S. Senate Ethics Committee “severely admonished” Democratic Sen. Bob Menendez on Thursday. Federal prosecutors months ago dropped a corruption case against the senator following a mistrial, Bloomberg reports.
RISK
Korean leaders to pursue peace deal. The leaders of North and South Korea agreed to pursue a peace agreement, but left uncertainties about the Pyongyang’s regime’s willingness to cede ground on its nuclear arsenal ahead of a meeting between Kim Jong Un and U.S. President Donald Trump, the WSJ reports.
Fujifilm to discuss altering Xerox deal. Fujifilm Holdings plans to discuss possible changes to its deal for a majority stake in Xerox Corp. , following a lawsuit by a Xerox investor. Fujifilm received a request from Xerox to renegotiate the terms announced in January, Fujifilm said, the WSJ reports.
Hog farm’s neighbors to get $50 million. A North Carolina jury ruled against pork producer Murphy-Brown LLC , which plans to appeal. Jurors awarded more than $50 million to 10 plaintiffs who live near a hog farm. The plaintiffs accused Murphy-Brown of failing to take necessary steps to eliminate odors and other nuisances, including pests, the WSJ reports.
Mexican airport, now being built, may be canceled. Andrés Manuel López Obrador, the clear front-runner ahead of July’s presidential election in Mexico, has vowed to cancel Mexico City’s $13.3 billion airport project if he wins. Around 70% of the contracts have already been awarded, according to government data, the WSJ reports. Construction is underway.
STRATEGY
Vitamin retailer to close some stores. GNC Holdings , the vitamin chain, plans to close approximately 200 stores in 2018 as it continues to turn around its business. GNC has thousands of stores globally, with 3,385 locations in the U.S. and Canada, the WSJ reports.
GNC Holdings has 3,385 stores in the U.S. and Canada. PHOTO: RICHARD B. LEVINE/ZUMA PRESS PEOPLE MOVES
Reed Smith hires a GE compliance officer. The law firm Reed Smith hired Lewis Zirogiannis, who has served as GE Digital’s chief compliance offier, for its global regulatory-enforcement practice, GE Digital is General Electric ‘s internet software business, the Recorder reports.
